pocket.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a type of small bag in or on a coat, trousers etc that you can put money, keys etc in
pocket.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Luke came in with his hands in his pockets.
The policeman told me to turn out my pockets  (=take everything out of them).
The keys are in my trouser pocket.
the inside pocket of his jacket
pocket.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the amount of money that you have to spend
pocket.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: There are eight hotels, with a price range to suit every pocket.
The deepening recession has hit people’s pockets.
For investors with deep pockets  (=a lot of money), the Berlin property market is attractive.
Dan had to pay for the repairs out of his own pocket.
He was accused of diverting some of the firm’s money into his own pocket.
pocket.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a small bag or piece of material fastened to something so that you can put things into it
pocket.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Please read the air safety card in the pocket of the seat in front.
pocket.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a small area or amount of something that is different from what surrounds it
pocket.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: In some parts, there are still pockets of violence and unrest.
pockets of air inside the hull of the ship
pocket.translation[0].definitions[4].def: a small net on a pool, snooker, or billiard table, which you try to hit balls into
pocket.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: put something in your pocket
I put the £5 note in my pocket.
stuff/thrust something in your pocket
He took off his cap and stuffed it in his pocket.
take something out of/from your pocket
Marcia took a pair of dark glasses out of her pocket.
reach into your pocket
"Do you want a cigarette?" he asked, reaching into his pocket.
search your pocket
I searched my pockets for my train ticket but it wasn't there.
turn out/empty your pockets
His mother made him turn out his pockets.
dig in your pocket
Boris dug in his pocket for his keys.
with your hands in your pockets
I saw him wandering along the beach with his hands in his pockets.
somebody's pockets are bulging
Tony's pockets were bulging with loose change.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + pocket
a back/front/side pocket
He took a wad of money from his back pocket.
a breast pocket
There was a silk handkerchief in his breast pocket.
an inside pocket
Gregson pulled a photo from the inside pocket of his jacket.
a jacket/trouser/shirt etc pocket
She slipped the map into her jacket pocket.
pocket.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to put something into your pocket
pocket.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Maggie locked the door and pocketed the keys.
pocket.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to steal money, especially money that you are responsible for
pocket.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: One inspector had pocketed up to $500,000 in bribes.
pocket.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to get a large amount of money, win a prize etc, especially in a way that seems very easy or slightly dishonest
pocket.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to hit a ball into a pocket in the game of pool, snooker or billiards
pocket.translation[2].definitions[0].def: small enough to be carried in your pocket
pocket.translation[3].definitions[0].def: used to refer to the amount of money people have available to spend
pocket.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: We need to find a way to put more money in people’s pockets.
a savings scheme to suit all pockets (=suitable however much money you have)
a company with deep pockets (=a lot of money)
pocket.translation[3].definitions[1].def: a small area or part of something where a situation is very different from other areas or parts
pocket.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Certain pockets of the aircraft market already have shown themselves to be vulnerable.
pocket.translation[3].definitions[2].def: to have less money than you should have after an event such as a business deal
pocket.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: All expenses will be paid. You won’t be out of pocket.
pocket.translation[3].definitions[3].def: to give money to someone who needs it
pocket.translation[3].definitions[4].def: to earn a lot of money, especially by using unfair methods
pocket.translation[3].definitions[4].exa: Banks are lining their pockets by charging their customers sky-high interest rates.
pocket.translation[4].definitions[0].def: a calculator, dictionary etc that is small enough to carry in your pocket
pocket.translation[5].definitions[0].def: to get money, especially in a slightly dishonest way or when you do not deserve it
pocket.translation[5].definitions[0].exa: For operating the network, Jefferies pockets about $60,000 a day.
He sold her car for more than she asked for, and pocketed the difference (=kept the extra money for himself).
pocket.translation[5].definitions[1].def: to steal money, especially money you are responsible for
pocket.translation[5].definitions[1].exa: The insurer had no record of the policy because the agent had pocketed the premiums.
